importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The day the lawsuit was filed, marking a key escalation in the dispute over the swearing-in of Congresswoman Adelita Grijalva.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Grijalva won her election on September 28, 2025, and the controversy over her swearing-in began shortly after, culminating in the lawsuit filed on October 21, 2025.

keyTakeAways: Arizona’s attorney general, Kris Mayes, filed a lawsuit against the U.S. House of Representatives over Speaker Mike Johnson’s refusal to swear in newly elected Democrat Adelita Grijalva.

The lawsuit argues that the Constitution requires elected representatives to be sworn in if they meet qualifications, and that no constitutional authority exists for the Speaker to unilaterally delay swearing-in.
Johnson claims he is following the precedent set by Nancy Pelosi during recesses, but the lawsuit asserts this precedent does not justify blocking the swearing-in of a duly elected representative.
The lawsuit alleges that Johnson’s delay is politically motivated, aimed at delaying a petition on Jeffrey Epstein records and strengthening his position in budget negotiations.
Grijalva has not spoken to Johnson since her election and is seeking a direct meeting to resolve the dispute.
The lawsuit seeks a court order allowing a qualified third party to administer the oath to Grijalva, as Johnson has not provided a valid reason for delay.
The case raises constitutional questions about the role of the Speaker in the swearing-in of members and the rights of newly elected representatives.

namedEntities.name: Kris Mayes
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is the lead legal figure filing the lawsuit to challenge Speaker Mike Johnson’s refusal to swear in a newly elected congresswoman, asserting constitutional rights of newly elected officials.

namedEntities.name: Adelita Grijalva
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is the newly elected representative whose swearing-in was blocked, making her central to the legal and political dispute over procedural and constitutional rights in Congress.

namedEntities.name: Mike Johnson
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is the political leader who refused to administer the oath of office to Grijalva, citing precedent, and is central to the constitutional and political controversy over the legitimacy of such a delay.

namedEntities.name: Nancy Pelosi
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is referenced as a precedent-setting figure whose actions during recesses are cited by Johnson to justify delaying the swearing-in of new members.

namedEntities.name: Jeffrey Epstein
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Controversial figure associated with sex trafficking allegations
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A petition to release Epstein-related records is cited as a possible political motive behind Johnson’s delay in swearing in Grijalva.

namedEntities.name: U.S. House of Representatives
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The body is the subject of the legal challenge, as the lawsuit questions the authority of its Speaker to delay seating a duly elected member.

namedEntities.name: Washington, D.C.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The lawsuit was filed in the federal court in Washington, D.C., indicating the legal venue and jurisdiction of the constitutional dispute.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Arizona’s attorney general, Kris Mayes, has filed a lawsuit against the U.S. House of Representatives, accusing Speaker Mike Johnson of violating constitutional principles by refusing to swear in newly elected Democrat Adelita Grijalva. Johnson claims he is following the precedent set by former Speaker Nancy Pelosi during recess periods, arguing that the House should not hold regular sessions during breaks. However, the lawsuit asserts that the Constitution requires newly elected members to be sworn in upon meeting qualifications, and that no authority exists for the Speaker to unilaterally delay this process. The case alleges that Johnson's delay is politically motivated, aimed at advancing a petition on Jeffrey Epstein records and strengthening his position in budget negotiations. Grijalva, who won her election in late September 2025, has not spoken to Johnson and is seeking a personal meeting to resolve the impasse. The lawsuit seeks a court order allowing a qualified official to administer the oath, as Johnson has not provided any legitimate reason for delay, and claims that the delay harms both Grijalva’s ability to serve and the interests of Arizona constituents.
title: Arizona Sues Over Mike Johnson’s Refusal to Swear In Democrats’ Newest Congresswoman
